content: The Chalcolithic culture flourishes in Maharashtra, with settlements like Inamgaon showcasing early agricultural and trading practices.
The Satavahana dynasty rises to power, promoting trade and cultural exchange along the Deccan plateau, with Pratishthana (modern Paithan) as its capital.
The Ajanta Caves are carved and painted, reflecting the zenith of Buddhist art and culture during the Satavahana period.
The Vakataka dynasty supports the arts, leading to the creation of the Ellora Caves, which depict a blend of Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain traditions.
The Rashtrakuta dynasty emerges, with their capital at Manyakheta and contributions to monumental architecture like the Kailasa Temple at Ellora.
The Yadava dynasty rules from Devagiri (modern-day Daulatabad), fostering Marathi as a literary and administrative language.
The Delhi Sultanate invades Devagiri, marking the beginning of Islamic influence in Maharashtra's culture and politics.
The Bahmani Sultanate fragments, leading to the establishment of the Ahmednagar Sultanate, a key player in Deccan politics.
The Mughal Empire consolidates power over Maharashtra, incorporating it into their vast empire.
Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj establishes the Maratha Empire, laying the foundation for an independent and powerful regional kingdom.
Shivaji Maharaj is crowned as the Chhatrapati of the Maratha Empire at Raigad Fort, marking the zenith of Maratha sovereignty.
The Third Anglo-Maratha War ends with the British East India Company defeating the Marathas, establishing control over Maharashtra.
Maharashtra actively participates in the Indian Rebellion of 1857, with leaders like Nana Sahib and Tatya Tope resisting British rule.
The Indian National Congress is founded in Mumbai, playing a pivotal role in India's independence movement.
Mahatma Gandhi launches the Non-Cooperation Movement, gaining significant support from Maharashtra, particularly Mumbai and Pune.
India gains independence, and Maharashtra emerges as a prominent center for industry, culture, and education in the newly formed nation.
The state of Maharashtra is formed, with Mumbai as its capital, following the division of the Bombay State along linguistic lines.
The Tarapur Atomic Power Station, India's first nuclear power plant, becomes operational in Maharashtra.
Mumbai witnesses a transformation as it officially sheds the colonial name 'Bombay,' embracing its regional identity.
The Elephanta Caves, showcasing ancient rock-cut architecture, are declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
The Bandra-Worli Sea Link opens in Mumbai, showcasing modern engineering and improving connectivity in Maharashtra's capital.
The Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport's new terminal receives global acclaim for its design and functionality.
Mumbai becomes one of the worst-hit cities during the COVID-19 pandemic, showcasing resilience in the face of crisis.
